snippet: Evidence appears to tie Tamerlan Tsarnaev to the deaths of three men in a Boston suburb, and some officials say a more vigorous inquiry might have led to his capture and prevented the marathon attack.
abstract: Evidence appears to tie deceased Boston Marathon bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev to the 2011 murders of three men in Boston suburb Waltham; some officials say a more vigorous inquiry at that time might have led to his capture and prevented marathon attacks; his younger brother Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appears in court for arraignment and pleads not guilty to all 30 counts against him.

byline.original: By SERGE F. KOVALESKI and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
byline.contributor: William K. Rashbaum contributed reporting from New York, Michael S. Schmidt from Washington, and Jess Bidgood from Boston. Sheelagh McNeill, Alain Delaquérière and Lisa Schwartz contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Evidence appears to tie Tamerlan Tsarnaev to the deaths of three men in a Boston suburb, and some officials say a more vigorous inquiry might have led to his capture and prevented the marathon attack.

headline.main: In 2011 Murder Inquiry, Hints of Missed Chance to Avert Boston Bombing
headline.print_headline: Bombing Suspect Is Seen as Linked To 2011 Slayings
